problem:
\begin{problem*}{}{}
  Let $a, b, c$ be three real numbers which are roots of a
  cubic polynomial, and satisfy $a+b+c=6$ and $ab+bc+ca=9$.
  Suppose $a<b<c$. Show that
  \[
    0<a<1<b<3<c<4
  .\]
\end{problem*}
solution:
\aopssoln{polarLines}{7}{https://aops.com/community/c6h2623388p22679817}

\begin{soln}
  Note that
  \[
    P(x) = (x-a)(x-b)(x-c)
    = x^3 - \left(\sum a\right)x^2
    + \left(\sum ab\right)x - abc
    = x^3-6x^2+9x-abc
  .\]

  Now $P'(x) = 3x^2 - 12x+9 = 3 (x-3)(x-1)$.
  Since the extrema occur at $x=1,3$ and we know that
  $P$ has three distinct real roots, it is clear that
  $a<1<b<3<c$. Also, this tells us that $P(1)>0$, $P(3)<0$.

  $P(3)<0\implies -abc = 3^3-6\times 3^2 +
  9\times 3 -abc < 0  \stackrel{b,c>0}{\implies} a>0$.

  We can observe that $P(4)=4-abc = P(1) >0$ as noted earlier.
  This gives $c<4$ by IVP.
\end{soln}
